data.text:
This is by far the most difficult post Iâve ever tried to write and thatâs because this is no ordinary post. This is in honor of Jack Lemmon, one of my cinematic loves.

âIf you really do want to be an actor who can satisfy himself and his audience, you need to be vulnerable. You must reach the emotional and intellectual level of ability where you can go out stark naked, emotionally, in front of an audience.â

One could look at Jack Lemmonâs illustrious career from a number of angles and therein lies my dilemma. He was a great comedian both in delivery and physicality and reached a depth in drama that few others could attain. He made every outrageous role he ever played relatable and every ordinary role extraordinary. Despite the fact he is best known for playing average working class men trying to get ahead in life, there was little that was average about Jack Lemmonâs acting. I donât think anyone else did what he did on screen. He had âit.â

What was âitâ? Well, âitâ was the way Lemmon portrayed comedy seriously and drama comically. He said in an interview I watched once that the wonderful thing about comedy is that âit can make dramatic points even deeper.â And thatâs how he seemed to approach either drama or comedy, with equal vigor, with the same attention to detail, with the same respect. Ultimately recognizing thatâs how things are in real life where there are few instances of pure joy or pure despair. Lemmon recognized life is layered, that people are layered that situations and circumstances are layered.

âItâs hard enough to write a good drama, itâs much harder to write a good comedy, and itâs hardest of all to write a drama with comedy. Which is what life is.â

Itâs no wonder Lemmon worked with the legendary Billy Wilder so often and that they created screen magic at every turn. Few writers and directors recognized and portrayed the human condition so effectively for the screen as did Billy Wilder. Jack was the perfect interpreter of Wilderâs words. Common yet memorable. Always genuine.

âHappiness is working with Jack Lemmon.â â Billy Wilder

Jack Lemmon didnât just play âeverymanâ effectively in Billy Wilder films, however. He did so in all his films. Of himself Lemmon said he was âA class clown that was serious underneath.â I suppose the idea of a clown who is sad is not new or unique. But to bring that to the screen so effectively in roles that are often distinctly either comedy or drama is unique. I can think of only Chaplin as another who was able to break your heart and make you laugh at the same time, who was so truthful it often hurt.

In an attempt to show the unique âtruthfulnessâ in Lemmonâs performances, from a fanâs perspective, I chose a few examples of scenes that stick out in my mind. These are not in any order and are just a few of the many that can be chosen from the more than 60 films Lemmon appeared in.

Iâll start with what is perhaps the most popular film Jack Lemmon was ever in, a perennial favorite, Billy Wilderâs 1959 classic, Some Like it Hot. The scene, âIâm a boyâ where Lemmonâs character, Jerry is playing the maracas in celebration of his impending nuptials to millionaire, Osgood Fielding, III. The obvious is that this is one of the funniest scenes in a very funny movie. It illustrates Lemmonâs gift for straight comedy. On the surface. In reality the effectiveness of the scene, the reason it works so well and why it is so memorable is due to how Lemmon chose to play it. Jerry is so caught up with Daphneâs good fortune that what we are seeing is Daphneâs excitement â a man who forgot for a few minutes that heâs a man dressed in womenâs clothes. He is genuinely excited heâs been proposed to by a millionaire. Remember, the scene opens and he is alone in the room, not forced to continue the charade. Who else but Lemmon can do this so convincingly? Without the truth he brings to this it would have been only outrageous. Itâs not. The situation is ridiculous but the character is not. As a result, the scene is funny on many levels. Sincere excitement followed by sincere disappointment. Heâs a boy!

Without pomp and circumstance, Jack Lemmonâs portrayals are always convincing. He became his characters. Often, with a look or a sigh, a certain posture or the manner in which he walked, we knew volumes about these men.

In 1968 Jack Lemmon costars with Walter Matthau for the second of ten times in the Gene Saks-directed, Neil Simon classic, The Odd Couple. Jack Lemmon plays the straight man in another very funny film â the neurotic, Felix Unger. Thatâs not to say Lemmon as Felix is not funny, because he is. But laughs donât come from witty repartee and outrageousness for him as they do for the Oscar character, played by Matthau. Felixâs laughs are often tinged with hurt. Layered. The scene I chose here is not a funny one. Itâs the scene that opens the film, which by Lemmonâs performance gives no inkling you are about to watch a comedy.

As The Odd Couple opens â we hear the familiar theme music, the paramount logo and then an aerial view of New York Cityâs Times Square followed by closer looks at other popular sites in the City. Then we see a man walking as the title sequence comes up. We can tell by his body language, demeanor, expression that he is completely lost. Not geographically, but emotionally.

The theme music barely stops and the man, whoâs now walked into a motel asks for a room. Two words and we get a closer look at his face. He is desperate, alone, on the verge of doing the unthinkable.

The manâs eyes are watery, droopy and bloodshot, his shoulders hunched, his voice heavy with emotion. Resigned. I know little about acting other than what I like or donât like, what âgets to meâ and what doesnât. This man gets to me. We then see the man in the room. He prepares the items heâll leave behind for his family, puts them in the envelope and steps over to open the window. But the windowâs stuck and he hurts his back in the effort. We are suddenly laughing because his wails are hilarious and somehow itâs funny that a man whoâs trying to kill himself is prevented from doing so because he hurts his back. Meet Felix Unger. With no dialogue Jack Lemmon has taken us from despair to hilarity in the span of a few minutes.

From that moment on The Odd Couple is a funny film with Jackâs physical comedy strengths playing a big part, not to downplay Matthauâs performance as Oscar Madison because heâs hilarious. Also, the chemistry between these two men is great. But Felixâs unforgettable sinus-clearing noises, the stiff neck, bad back, the nagging. All memorable because they are all done so truthfully. Lemmon embodies this character as he did them all.

Since Iâm on the subject of a Neil Simon play-turned film â Simon wrote a play thatâs a very funny take on the biblical story of Job, titled âGodâs Favoriteâ that was produced for the stage in 1974. Iâm familiar with it because I was in a really bad production of it in school but thatâs a story for another day. That particular play never made it to the screen but two subsequent films written by Simon that to me have very similar plots to the Job story did and both star Jack Lemmon, The Out of Towners (1970) directed by Arthur Hiller and Prisoner of Second Avenue (1975) directed by Melvin Frank. Lemmonâs co-stars in these are Sandy Dennis and Anne Bancroft, respectively. I happened to watch both of these back-to-back recently and noticed that they are very similar in the sense that both are about people who are tested over and over again. Like Job, they are pushed to the edge.

Expectedly, Jack Lemmon is great in both films. No one plays desperation like he does while always keeping humor just below the surface ready to spring. But his performance in Prisoner of Second Avenue is astounding. One of his best, in my opinion and thatâs something considering he could do no wrong in my eyes. Here, as is often the case, I am most blown away when he says absolutely nothing.

Such poignancy in an incredibly funny film. Despite quip after quip, funny repartee, and incredible circumstances the truth is his character, Mel, is deeply disillusioned, at the end of his rope and thereâs nothing funny about that. No one could have given such a role in such a film the depth given it by Jack Lemmon. He breaks my heart â in another comedy. His acting choices are the choices of âtrue-to-life.â Instead of choosing what would make a scene funnier, he always chose to go the sincere route.

In 1966 Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau acted together for the first time in Billy Wilderâs, The Fortune Cookie. This was the start of not only a ârealâ beautiful friendship, but one of the best and most successful on-screen partnerships in film history. In The Fortune Cookie, Jack Lemmon stars as Harry Hinkle, a cameraman whoâs mildly hurt while filming a football game. While heâs in the hospital getting checked out, his brother-in-law, Willie Gingrich, whoâs also an ambulance-chasing attorney, âWhip-lash Willie,â railroads him into feigning serious injury so they can sue for $1 million. As is the case with The Odd Couple, Lemmon plays the more subdued role in this film and I might add Walter Matthau is great here. But, Lemmonâs understated performance and incredible physicality are (yet again) unforgettable. Part of the âactâ requires Harry be bound to a wheelchair for most of the movie â something that simply enhances vulnerability, another familiar Jack Lemmon character trait, no matter how much of a smart alec he may play. Even with those limitations, Jack is impressive.

And then THE shot. Realization sets in for Harry that his wife, whoâd left him for another man earlier, has returned only because heâs likely to get a million dollars from the suit. The eyes â how deep is the hurt here?

A couple of weeks ago I took a look at James Foleyâs, Glengarry Glen Ross (1992), based on David Mametâs play, which is the only Jack Lemmon film included here that I needed a refresher on, the one I hadnât seen in a long while. The film features an outstanding ensemble cast, including Al Pacino, Alan Arkin and Alec Baldwin, all veteran actors whose work I admire. This film, in case you havenât seen it, is about the dog-eat-dog world of salesmen in a real estate office. Itâs a brutal film, for no one more than Lemmonâs character, Sheldon âThe Machineâ Levene who is perhaps the most ethically compromised of all the characters in the film and there is not one character with ethics. So Iâm sitting there watching this thing and am just blown away by Jack Lemmon. I wish I could say something original but heâs simply stupendous. Among several great performances his is heads above everyone elseâs.

I will add that I saw an interview with Jack Lemmon where he discussed Glengarry and his character. He said he wanted to be sure to never come across as a man who deserves sympathy. But he does to me so I have to say that. Thereâs no doubt this guy is ruthless but, the situations in his life are worthy of sympathy. Regardless, his pain is genuine, palpable â itâs just something to see â whatever the motivation. There is no comedy in this one butâ¦just so memorable.

The winner of the Academy Award for Best Picture in 1961 is a little ditty written and director by Billy Wilder and starring Jack Lemmon. There is, at first glance or on paper, whichever way you want to say it, nothing about this film that should touch people the way it does , yet The Apartment is simply stupendous. Iâve watched this film many times and knowing the impact it has in its entirety, the filmâs opening never fails to make me smile. The protagonist, C. C. Baxter introduces the film in a voiceover. As we take a look at where he works, in one of a sea of desks, in the ordinary policy department, we are told, in no uncertain terms, that this is an ordinary guy in an ordinary place at an ordinary time. Nothing special. Then why is this such a memorable film that only gets better every time you watch it? This is the genius of Wilderâs writing and directing and casting, of course, because this particular ordinary guy is Jack Lemmon. For all his ordinariness (is that a word?) he is unforgettable â charming, somewhat clumsy, desperate, disillusioned and oh so vulnerable.

My favorite scene in The Apartment is what I call âthe heartbreak scene,â when C. C. looks in the broken compact mirror and comes to the realization that the woman he loves, Miss Kubelik (Shirley MacLaine) is the one whoâs been canoodling in his own apartment with his boss. The familiar, touching, raw emotion weâre so used to seeing from Jack Lemmon and what distinguishes him from the rest of the pack. You can see the heartbreak through the reflection of a broken compact mirror and then the bad taste the entire affair leaves in his mouth.

Billy Wilder made some of the best films ever made, in my opinion. And part of their appeal is the wonderful way he ends them. There are many unforgettable endings in his repertoire (see Billy Wilder Speaks). And part of what makes them unforgettable is the fact that they are not necessarily spectacular but true to the characters. These also donât necessarily conclude the story. We are charmed and awed to the very last shot. The Apartment has one of those endings. C. C. Baxter is not a cynical womanizer at the end of the film. He and his sweetheart are not on their way off into the sunset. One hopes so but we canât be sure. Baxter is still ordinary in the end. He hasnât scaled Everest. Heâs just stood up for himself â and professed his love.

In 1979 Jack Lemmon starred in James Bridgesâ, The China Syndrome alongside Jane Fonda and Michael Douglas. The subject of the film was something Jack Lemmon was passionate about in real life, the environment. For that reason, and because once again he delivered a wonderful performance in it, this time in a terrific thriller, are the reasons Iâm including it in this post.

The China Syndrome deals with possible dangers associated with a nuclear power plant. Itâs a film that offers an audience, to this day, a lot to think about because, by choice, the film doesnât take any one stance â pro or con â with regard to the very serious and controversial topic it deals with. That said, itâs the performances here that make this film so good. Jane Fonda shows great range and sheâs excellent as a reporter of âfluffâ pieces who wants to be taken seriously and stumbles upon a major story. Michael Douglas fits his part perfectly, the independent, anti-establishment, cameraman who works with Fondaâs character who stumbles onto this story with her. Then thereâs Jack Lemmon who plays a key worker at the nuclear power plant whoâs reluctant to rock the boat but grapples with his conscience, which wonât let him stand on the sidelines. I canât help but be redundant, Lemmon creates a very complex character in Jack Godell. A performance as memorable and moving as is his Oscar-winning one as Harry Stoner in John Avidsenâs, Save the Tiger (1973). In fact, if I had to choose between the two, Iâd choose The China Syndrome.

Of acting Jack Lemmon once said, âIt is a glorious profession. Not just a nice one, but truly glorious and as Shakespeare put it, it is truly noble â the reason being is that as actors, at least once, we are put in a position that very few people on the face of the earth are put in â a position where you can actually change somebodyâs life. You can affect them that much. You can move them and enlighten themâ¦and make them think what they have never thought before.â

Walter Matthau was a presenter when Jack Lemmon received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Film Institute in 1988. In his speech, of Jack he said, âI figured my knowing him so well was the reason he always seemed so familiar up there on the screen. Itâs not. Itâs just what he does. He allows us to see the tragedy and the comedy of the world through the eyes of someone we know, someone he hints we may even be. Because in the words of the poet and philosopher, Billy Wilder, âmost actors can show you one or two things and theyâve emptied their shelves. Jack Lemmon is Macyâs and Tiffanyâs and Sears Roebuck, catalog and all.â

The man who was ridiculed in school because his full name was Jack U. Lemmon, grew up to become one of the greatest film actors who ever lived. An actor of extraordinary range. An unpretentious actorâs actor of whom PBS journalist Charlie Rose once said, had a career that âtook one of the greatest acting journeys of our time.â A self-taught accomplished pianist. A Harvard graduate. A lovely man. An extraordinarily ordinary face. All of that adds up to the magic of Lemmon.
